awd_titl_txt: Measurement of Negative Mentoring in Undergraduate Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Undergraduate research experiences are known to foster students' personal and professional growth.  Prior studies have demonstrated that positive mentoring experiences have positive effects on undergraduate researchers.  However, the prevalence and impact of negative mentoring experiences have not been systematically investigated.  Such experiences would be expected to have detrimental impacts on the undergraduate researchers.  This project aims to develop, test, and use new survey instruments to measure the incidence and impact of negative mentoring on undergraduate researchers in the life sciences. Analysis of the results will provide information about the frequency of negative mentoring, its effects on undergraduate student researchers, and possible actions to reduce or prevent it. This project will also provide insights on the effect of negative mentoring on undergraduates from backgrounds that are historically under-represented or under-served. 

This project aims to accomplish three major goals: define a construct of negative mentoring in undergraduate research, produce a valid and reliable measure of negative mentoring in undergraduate research, and conduct a preliminary investigation of the impacts of negative mentoring. Following established guidelines for developing new psychological measures, the project will begin by interviewing a diverse group of undergraduate student researchers who have experienced negative mentoring.  Analysis of their responses will define a construct of negative mentoring in undergraduate research. A large pool of undergraduate students nationwide will take a draft survey based on this construct.  Results of this survey will provide preliminary insight into the effects of negative mentoring and helping to inform refinements of the survey instruments. Administering the refined survey instrument to undergraduate student researchers nationwide will increase understanding of the impact of negative mentoring on undergraduate research outcomes. This project has the potential to yield insights and produce tools that could help improve the quality of undergraduate research mentoring. This project will also test interventions aimed at reducing or preventing negative mentoring and its impacts.  These results can contribute to improving undergraduate research experiences so that their potential to build STEM talent and broaden participation in STEM can be realized.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Undergraduate research experiences (UREs) are championed for their potential to foster undergraduates’ personal and professional growth. Mentoring by more experienced scientists, including graduate students, postdoctoral associates, and faculty members, is considered an essential element of UREs. Studies from our own group and others have examined mentoring in UREs, with a focus on positive mentoring that undergraduates experience. However, studies from workplace settings have shown that not all mentoring relationships are positive. In addition, our preliminary research suggested that undergraduate researchers do indeed experience negative mentoring.

Given widespread recommendations to involve undergraduate STEM students in research and the potential for negative mentoring to cause harm, it is critical to understand the mentoring that undergraduate researchers experience and how it affects them. Accomplishing this requires an instrument with strong evidence of its utility for measuring the range of mentoring experienced by undergraduate researchers. This project developed such a measure: the Mentoring in Undergraduate Research Survey (MURS). To develop the MURS, we:

  • Collected and analyzed undergraduate researchers’ qualitative accounts of their negative mentoring experiences,
  • Used undergraduates’ accounts to draft a survey measure of negative mentoring; and
  • Collected and analyzed two large datasets from a national sample of undergraduate researchers to test the quality and utility of the measure.

Through this multi-step process, we defined and characterized negative mentoring experiences of undergraduate life science researchers. Furthermore, we identified seven forms of mentoring that undergraduate researchers experience that including both supportive experiences, such as receiving technical and psychosocial support, and destructive experiences, such as abusive supervision and unfair treatment (see Figure: Factors of Mentoring in Undergraduate Research).

Although most undergraduates we studied reported experiencing supportive mentoring, some reported experiencing absence of supportive as well as destructive experiences (see Figure: Negative mentoring experienced by life science undergraduate researchers). Undergraduates who experienced less supportive and more destructive mentoring also experienced lower integration into the scientific community and a dampening of their beliefs about the value of research.

This project is intellectually meritorious because it:

  • Defined negative mentoring in undergraduate research, which had not been conceptualized or operationalized despite the fact that it occurs, and it has potential to cause harm;
  • Applied rigorous standards and methods of psychological measurement to the study of undergraduate research; and
  • Provided evidence that undergraduates with different personal characteristics did not differ in the prevalence of experiencing negative mentoring or its effects.

This project has been impactful because it produced the MURS as a high-quality measure of negative mentoring in undergraduate research. This freely available tool can be used to study the prevalence and impact of negative mentoring in undergraduate research experiences, evaluate undergraduate research programs to make improvements over time, and test the effectiveness of interventions aimed at mitigating or preventing negative mentoring.

For more information about this work and to access the MURS:

Limeri, L. B., Asif, M. Z., Bridges, B. H. T., Esparza, D., Tuma, T. T., Sanders, D., Morrison, A. J., Rao, P., Harsh, J. A., Maltese, A. V., & Dolan, E. L. (2019). “Where’s My Mentor?!” Characterizing Negative Mentoring Experiences in Undergraduate Life Science Research. CBE—Life Sciences Education, 18(4), ar61. https://doi.org/10.1187/cbe.19-02-0036

Limeri, L. B., Carter, N. T., Hess, R. A., Tuma, T. T., Koscik, I., Morrison, A. J., Outlaw, B., Royston, K. S., Bridges, B. H. T., & Dolan, E. L. (2024). Development of the Mentoring in Undergraduate Research Survey. CBE—Life Sciences Education, 23(2), ar26. https://doi.org/10.1187/cbe.23-07-0141
